docs.lead_paragraph: It is a testament to Yankee know-how that actual rocket scientists are seeking the input of “basement brainstormers” and “garage tinkerers” in the NASA-sponsored contests. I found Jack Hitt’s (July 1) mention of an unnamed oil sheik, who was wary of stimulating our nation’s famous ingenuity, ironic. Perhaps we would not be jeopardized by our dependence on Middle Eastern oil today if similar contests, stimulating innovations on alternative energy sources, had been instituted in the mid-70s when we were hit by the first of many oil shocks.

headline.print_headline: Letters; The Amateur Future of Space Travel

docs.lead_paragraph: As a lawyer representing health care providers, including doctors who have allegedly overprescribed narcotics, I read Tina Rosenberg's article (June 17) with great interest. Our government's focus on prison as a problem-solver has ruined Dr. McIver's life. The chilling effect on the medical profession cannot be measured or overstated. Particularly in rural areas, where specialists are rare or nonexistent, doctors fear prescribing adequately for patients in pain. As the baby boomers age, there will be more patients and fewer doctors. Those doctors not behind bars will be reluctant to adequately treat the increasing numbers of aging citizens with chronic conditions, some of which can bring excruciating pain.
docs.abstract: Donna Moniz letter comments on June 17 article on legal risks doctors run when they aggressively treat patients' pain
